xyz.acygn.mokapot

Interface Copiable

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    CommunicationAddress, CopiableRunnable, CopiableSupplier<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    LoopbackCommunicationAddress, SiteLocalCommunicationAddress, StaticInternetCommunicationAddress, TCPCommunicationAddress

    public interface Copiable
    A marker interface specifying that an object can be safely replaced with a copy/clone without changing the semantics of the program. If an object is explicitly marked as Copiable, then the distributed communication system will always maintain a copy of the object on each virtual machine that needs it, rather than trying to maintain a reference to it.

    As such, an object should only be marked as Copiable if this copying behaviour will not affect the program's functionality. In addition, because the object may be copied back and forth repeatedly, large objects should not be marked as Copiable for efficiency reasons.

    The copying will be done field by field. If the fields are Copiable themselves (or effectively copiable, such as String and primitives), they will be copied too, recursively, meaning that the Copiable portion of the object will be deeply copied. If a field is not Copiable, it must be an object reference; this will be copied as another reference to the same object, i.e. a shallow copy is performed in this case.

    Due to implementation details of Java, if a Copiable interface might potentially hold an object generated via a lambda expression, the interface must also be declared Serializable. (Otherwise, it's impossible to extract enough information from the lambda to reconstruct it

    Note that if you declare a class as Copiable, you should seriously consider it as Serializable too if it happens to obey the restrictions of Serializable (i.e. all fields are themselves Serializable, or can be made so). An object can be Copiable even if it cannot be serialised via the built-in Java mechanism (e.g. if it contains references to nonserialisable objects), and thus Copiable does not require Serializable, but the combination can be significantly more efficient than Copiable on its own.

    Author:
    Alex Smith
    See Also:
    NonCopiable
